item.title: A New Framework for Financing Global Security
item.description: Rather than improving global security, surging military expenditure threatens to deepen geopolitical instability, destroy ecosystems, fuel arms races, raise conflict risks, and crowd out public investment in other priorities, not least development aid. It doesn't have to be this way.

item.title: Trump’s Immigration Crackdown Isn't Working
item.description: Some right-wing political leaders view Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown as a model to emulate. But a closer look at the numbers confirms that, while denouncing foreigners can be politically fruitful, attempting to get rid of them is both economically costly and demonstrably futile.

item.title: Benin’s Failed Coup and the Future of African Democracy
item.description: The recent explosion of coups and coup plots in West Africa, most recently in Benin, suggests that the region's performative approach to Western-style democracy is running out of steam. While democracy itself is not dead, the continent most likely is heading toward more varied forms of political organization.

item.title: Will the EU’s Blacklisting of Russia Make a Difference?
item.description: The European Commission has finally added Russia to its list of “high-risk” third countries with strategic deficiencies in their anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing controls. item.title: The Far Right’s Gender Playbook
item.description: Around the world, authoritarian leaders are weaponizing gender-based grievances to rally supporters and roll back women’s and LGBTQ+ rights. item.title: Ten Years After the Paris Agreement, Let’s Redouble Efforts

Since then, France has fully embraced a leadership role, placing ecology at the heart of its energy, agricultural, and industrial policies.

item.title: Trump’s Ethnonational Security Strategy

item.title: The Global Economy’s Hidden Rebalancing
item.description: Although the global growth rate in 2026 is projected to be almost the same as it was in 2025, the headline figure belies deeper structural shifts in capital flows and comparative advantage. These shifts are the real story, because they are quietly reshaping how global savings and investment interact over the coming decade.

item.title: How Global AI Governance Could Work
item.description: Societies differ in their views on privacy, experimentation, market openness, and safety, so no single regulatory model can ever accommodate everyone’s preferences.
